title: Two Red Sox outfielders earn Gold Glove Awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox outfielders Wilyer Abreu and Ceddanne Rafaela won 2025 Gold Glove Awards for their defensive performances.
Abreu, winning for the second consecutive year, led A.L. right fielders with eight Outs Above Average and seven runs prevented.
Rafaela, a first-time winner, led A.L. centerfielders with 21 Outs Above Average and 19 runs prevented, trailing only one MLB player.

title: Middle school principal in Maine draws criticism after dressing as ICE agent for Halloween
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Black, Mt. Blue Middle School principal, criticized for wearing ICE agent costume for Halloween.
Superintendent Christian Elkington stated the incident occurred off school grounds and is under district review.
Advocacy group Project Relief Maine called the costume terrifying for immigrant students and inappropriate.

title: What Christian Gonzalez said about his head injury
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Christian Gonzalez left the Patriots game with a head injury but was later cleared after passing concussion protocol.
The injury occurred during a play with Atlanta's Drake London, who caught a 40-yard pass over Gonzalez.
Gonzalez expressed readiness to return, but the Patriots' offense secured the win, negating his need to re-enter.

title: South End residents say they picked up 180 needles in less than a week at neighborhood park
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Volunteers collected 180 needles in six days from the Southwest Corridor Park in Boston's South End.
South End residents and officials urge city action against open drug use and needle littering in public parks.
Boston distributes over 81,000 needles monthly for harm reduction, but officials call for reductions and recovery solutions.

title: What Kevin Durant said about Jayson Tatum’s Achilles recovery, chances of returning this year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kevin Durant praised Jayson Tatum's progress in Achilles injury recovery, noting Tatum's confidence in dunking six months post-surgery.
Tatum's potential season return marks a significant shift from expected recovery timelines, suggesting advancements in medical treatment.
Durant believes Tatum's return is feasible, with Tatum leaving open the possibility of playing in the 2025-26 NBA season.

title: Amid tragedy, childhood friends DeMario Douglas and Terrell Jennings persevere in Patriots’ win
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: DeMario Douglas and Terrell Jennings honored a mutual acquaintance's death with standout performances in Patriots' 24-23 win over Falcons.
Douglas achieved his first 100-yard NFL game and caught a touchdown, while Jennings scored his first career touchdown.
Jennings succeeded despite earlier homelessness and being a practice squad player, while Douglas has re-emerged as a key player.

title: Mike Vrabel shares message to Patriots, Drake Maye after nail-biting win over Falcons
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots win 24-23 against the Falcons at Gillette Stadium despite turnovers and defensive issues.
Drake Maye recorded 259 passing yards with two touchdowns but committed two turnovers influencing 10 Atlanta points.
Mike Vrabel emphasizes joy in playing amidst New England's mixed performance, encouraging the team to stay positive.

title: Former Newton Mayor Setti Warren dies ‘unexpectedly’ at 55
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Former Newton Mayor Setti Warren died unexpectedly at his home in Newton at 55, cause of death not disclosed.
Warren was Newton's first African American mayor, serving from 2009 to 2018; he contributed to education and city planning.
He was Director of the Institute of Politics at Harvard, remembered for mentorship and fostering political engagement.

title: Patriots stock watch: Here’s who stood out and struggled against Falcons
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: DeMario Douglas had a breakout performance with his first career 100-yard game, including a 58-yard catch.
Drake Maye was productive but had two costly turnovers, contributing to a closer game against the Falcons.
Marcus Jones struggled defensively as Atlanta capitalized on height mismatches for two touchdowns in the red zone.

title: Boston residents say they feel safer downtown compared to last year in new survey
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A new Downtown Boston Neighborhood Association survey shows 33.7% feel less safe downtown, down from 70.6% last year.
The Downtown Boston Public Safety Summit discussed issues like drug use, petty crime, and cleanliness on November 2, 2025.
Retail vacancies are at their lowest since COVID-19, attributed to increased safety and business opportunities downtown.
